title: نِعْمَ وَبِئْسَ
description: Learn about نِعْمَ وَبِئْسَ, the invariable verbs used for praise (نِعْمَ) and blame (بِئْسَ), including their فَاعِل and مَخْصُوص structures.

notes.title: What are أفعال المدح والذم?
content: نِعْمَ and بِئْسَ are special verbs called أَفْعَال المَدْح وَالذَّمّ (verbs of praise and blame). They are جَامِدَة (frozen/invariable) - they don't conjugate like regular verbs.
نِعْمَ is used for praise (المدح), meaning 'how excellent!' or 'what a great...' بِئْسَ is used for blame (الذم), meaning 'how evil!' or 'what a terrible...'
keyPoints: They don't change for gender, number, or tense

examples.english: What an excellent man Zayd is!
What a terrible trait lying is!
What an excellent friend the book is!
What a terrible drink wine is!

notes.title: Structure: الفاعل and المخصوص
content: These verbs require two components: الفَاعِل (the general noun with ال or مضاف إلى معرفة) and المَخْصُوص بالمدح أو الذم (the specific thing being praised or blamed).
In نِعْمَ الرَّجُلُ زَيْدٌ: الرَّجُلُ is the فاعل (general category), and زَيْدٌ is المخصوص (the specific person being praised).
keyPoints: الفاعل: معرفة بـ ال or مضاف (الرجل، رجلُ القوم)
المخصوص comes after and is مرفوع
إعراب المخصوص: مبتدأ مؤخر أو خبر لمبتدأ محذوف

examples.english: What an excellent Commander of Believers Umar is!
What a terrible trait for a man - stinginess!

notes.title: Types of الفاعل
content: The فاعل of نِعْمَ وَبِئْسَ can take several forms: معرفة بـ ال (definite with ال), مضاف إلى معرفة (construct with definite), or a ضمير مستتر (hidden pronoun) followed by تمييز.
With ما or مَنْ, they act as the فاعل when referring to a general relative meaning: نِعْمَ مَا تَفْعَلُ (excellent is what you do).
keyPoints: مضاف إلى معرفة: نِعْمَ رَجُلُ الْقَوْمِ
ضمير + تمييز: نِعْمَ رَجُلًا زَيْدٌ (he is excellent as a man)
ما/من: نِعْمَ مَا صَنَعْتَ (what you made is excellent)

examples.english: What an excellent leader Khalid is!
Excellent is the army's leader - Khalid!
Abu Bakr is excellent as a man!
And if you hide them... how excellent it is (Quran 2:271)

notes.title: Quranic Examples and Usage
content: نِعْمَ وَبِئْسَ appear frequently in the Quran. Allah uses them to praise the believers and their qualities, and to blame the disbelievers and evil traits.
Other verbs of praise and blame include: حَبَّذَا (how lovely!), سَاءَ (how evil!), and لَا حَبَّذَا (how unlovely!). These follow similar patterns.
keyPoints: Other blame verbs: سَاءَ، لَا حَبَّذَا

examples.english: Excellent is the servant - indeed he was one who turned back (Quran)
How wretched is the abode of the arrogant (Quran)
Evil as an example is the people (Quran)

exercises.promptEn: Abu Bakr is excellent as a _____! (tamyiz)

exercises.prompt: What an excellent servant Ayyub (Job) is!
What a terrible friend the liar is!
What an excellent leader Khalid is!
